translated: Jātaka
The Collection of Eight
The Chapter on Kaccāna
The Indra-jātaka
“The one who, out of desire,
goes under the control of the senses,
he, having abandoned both worlds,

analyzed: jīvantaḥ iva visussati  sukhassa anantaram  dukkhassa anantaram
translated: dries up while still living. 🔽After happiness comes suffering, 🔽after suffering comes happiness;
you have attained suffering and happiness,
the best is to expect happiness.
At the time of difficulty, the one who endures difficulty,
who does not transgress difficulty,
that wise one, after difficulty,
attains the attainment of happiness.

analyzed: na ha iva kāmāna kāmā  nānatthāḥ na attha kāraṇā
translated: Not only because of desires, 🔽not because of different goals or reasons,
not because of what is done or not done,
can you escape from the Dhamma by dying.”

analyzed: dakkham gahapatī sādhu  sa vibhajjan ca bhojana
translated: “Skillful is the householder, good, 🔽and sharing food;
not laughing at gains and losses,
not agitated by loss and gain.”
“This much is wisdom,
even Devī said this;
there is nothing worse than this,
than going under the control of the senses.”
“As if in the hands of enemies,
I have fallen into your power;
I will see what is to be done and what is to be known,
and the softness of virtue,
and having lost all that glory,
I am released from those deeds.
Though I have a thousand lives,
I have no relatives, no protector,
I have fallen from the noble Dhamma,
just like a dead man.
Having caused suffering for those who desire happiness,
I have come to this state;
I do not attain happiness,
I stand like a mute.”
The Jātaka of the Sense-Faculties is the seventh.
